description.narrative: As a flexible and fully un-earmarked humanitarian pooled fund it is also well aligned with Ireland’s Grand Bargain commitment to un-earmarked funding. In order to address any sudden onset crisis or emergency that may arise, a humanitarian funding reserve is maintained to ensure that Ireland is in a position to respond rapidly and flexibly, either through a call for proposals or bilateral engagement with a pre-identified partner, depending on which organisations are best placed to respond. Humanitarian Unit may proactively initiate a ‘Call for Proposals’ to NGOs through the Dóchas Humanitarian Aid Working Group (HAWG) to respond rapidly and effectively to a sudden onset disaster or to a deterioration in a protracted emergency situation, as and when needed.

The Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF) is a UN humanitarian funding instrument, managed by the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (UNOCHA). It releases money rapidly when a crisis occurs or when there is a sudden escalation of an existing crisis and responds to underfunded emergencies. It is a rapid response mechanism that aims to have funds on the ground within 72 hours of a crisis occurring, thereby kick-starting life-saving humanitarian response. It also strengthens core elements of humanitarian response in underfunded crises by responding to critical gaps.
